panels.content:
This dashboard shows health metrics for the read path. It is broken into sections for each service on the read path, and organized by the order in which the read request flows.
Incoming queries travel from the gateway → query frontend → query scheduler → querier → ingester and/or store-gateway (depending on the time range of the query).
For each service, there are 3 panels showing (1) requests per second to that service, (2) average, median, and p99 latency of requests to that service, and (3) p99 latency of requests to each instance of that service.

The dashboard also shows metrics for the 4 optional caches that can be deployed: the query results cache, the metadata cache, the chunks cache, and the index cache.
These panels will show “no data” if the caches are not deployed.

Lastly, it also includes metrics for how the ingester and store-gateway interact with object storage.

panels.description:
### Instant queries per second
Rate of instant queries per second being made to the system.
Includes both queries made to the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API as
well as queries from the ruler.
panels.title: Instant queries / sec

panels.description:
### Range queries per second
Rate of range queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Range queries / sec

panels.description:
### "Label names" queries per second
Rate of "label names" endpoint queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Label names queries / sec

panels.description:
### "Label values" queries per second
Rate of specific "label values" endpoint queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Label values queries / sec

panels.description:
### Series queries per second
Rate of series queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Series queries / sec

panels.description:
### Requests / sec

The query scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If this service is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Requests / sec

panels.description:
### Latency (Time in Queue)

The query scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If this service is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Latency (Time in Queue)

panels.description:
### Queue length

The query scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If this service is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue length

panels.description:
### 99th Percentile Latency by Queue Dimension

The query scheduler can optionally create subqueues in order to enforce round-robin query queuing fairness across additional queue dimensions beyond the default. By default, query queuing fairness is only applied by tenant ID. Queries without additional queue dimensions are labeled 'none'.
panels.title: 99th Percentile Latency by Queue Dimension

panels.description:
### 50th Percentile Latency by Queue Dimension

The query scheduler can optionally create subqueues in order to enforce round-robin query queuing fairness across additional queue dimensions beyond the default. By default, query queuing fairness is only applied by tenant ID. Queries without additional queue dimensions are labeled 'none'.
panels.title: 50th Percentile Latency by Queue Dimension

panels.description:
### Average Latency by Queue Dimension

The query scheduler can optionally create subqueues in order to enforce round-robin query queuing fairness across additional queue dimensions beyond the default. By default, query queuing fairness is only applied by tenant ID. Queries without additional queue dimensions are labeled 'none'.
panels.title: Average Latency by Queue Dimension

rows.title: Query-scheduler Latency (Time in Queue) Breakout by Additional Queue Dimensions

targets.expr:
histogram_quantile(0.99, sum(
  # Backwards compatibility
  rate(thanos_memcached_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
  or
  rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
) by (le)) * 1e3

histogram_quantile(0.50, sum(
  # Backwards compatibility
  rate(thanos_memcached_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
  or
  rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
) by (le)) * 1e3

sum(
  # Backwards compatibility
  rate(thanos_memcached_operation_duration_seconds_sum{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
  or
  rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_sum{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
) * 1e3
/
sum(
  # Backwards compatibility
  rate(thanos_memcached_operation_duration_seconds_count{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
  or
  rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_count{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((query-frontend.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))", name="frontend-cache"}[$__rate_interval])
)

panels.description:
### Replicas
The maximum, and current number of querier replicas.
Please note that the current number of replicas can still show 1 replica even when scaled to 0.
Since HPA never reports 0 replicas, the query will report 0 only if the HPA is not active.
panels.title: Replicas

panels.description:
### Scaling metric (desired replicas)
This panel shows the result scaling metric exposed by KEDA divided by the target/threshold used.
It should represent the desired number of replicas, ignoring the min/max constraints which are applied later.

targets.expr:
sum by (scaler) (
  label_replace(
    keda_scaler_metrics_value{cluster=~"$cluster", exported_namespace=~"$namespace"},
    "namespace", "$1", "exported_namespace", "(.*)"
  )
  /
  on(cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric) group_left
  label_replace(label_replace(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_target_metric{cluster=~"$cluster", namespace=~"$namespace", horizontalpodautoscaler=~"keda-hpa-querier"},
      "metric", "$1", "metric_name", "(.+)"
  ), "scaledObject", "$1", "horizontalpodautoscaler", "keda-hpa-(.*)")
)

panels.title: Scaling metric (desired replicas)

panels.description:
### Autoscaler failures rate
The rate of failures in the KEDA custom metrics API server. Whenever an error occurs, the KEDA custom
metrics server is unable to query the scaling metric from Prometheus so the autoscaler woudln't work properly.

targets.expr:
sum by(cluster, namespace, scaler, metric, scaledObject) (
  label_replace(
    rate(keda_scaler_errors[$__rate_interval]),
    "namespace", "$1", "exported_namespace", "(.+)"
  )
) +
on(cluster, namespace, metric, scaledObject) group_left
label_replace(
  label_replace(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_target_metric{cluster=~"$cluster", namespace=~"$namespace", horizontalpodautoscaler=~"keda-hpa-querier"} * 0,
      "scaledObject", "$1", "horizontalpodautoscaler", "keda-hpa-(.*)"
  ),
  "metric", "$1", "metric_name", "(.+)"
)

panels.title: Autoscaler failures rate

rows.title: Store-gateway – key-value store for store-gateways ring

targets.expr:
histogram_quantile(0.99, sum(
  # Backwards compatibility
  rate(thanos_memcached_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="index-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])
  or
  rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="index-cache"
}

) by (le)) * 1e3

  operation="getmulti",

  name="index-cache"

[$__rate_interval])

  # Backwards compatibility

  name="index-cache"

[$__rate_interval])
  or
  rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_sum{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="index-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])
) * 1e3
/
sum(
  # Backwards compatibility
  rate(thanos_memcached_operation_duration_seconds_count{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="index-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])
  or

  component="store-gateway",
  name="index-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])
)

panels.description:
### Hit ratio
Even if you do not set up memcached for the blocks index cache, you will still see data in this panel because the store-gateway by default has an
in-memory blocks index cache.
panels.title: Hit ratio
